sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for derived form IV (yes / no and example!).

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The author notes "nur in Bildungswortschatz (aznab, aslam, aṣbaḥ u.e.a.)"
The author (Talay 1999:125) states that the IV stem is now only preserved in a few remnants, mostly derived from Classical Arabic or Bedouin Arabic. Example: aslam - yəslam "to become a Muslim"
The author notes "nur in Bildungswortschatz (aznab, aslam, aṣbaḥ u.e.a.)"
The author (Fink 2017:88) notes that form IV is not attested. Verbs of the IV form in Standard Arabic lost the affix ʔa and are expressed with stem I (rād - īrīd instead of ʔarāda - yurīdu)
Löhr (1905:45) notes that stem IV is not used very frequently.
The author notes "nur in Bildungswortschatz (aznab, aslam, aṣbaḥ u.e.a.)"
The author notes "als geschlossene Klasse noch vorhanden (iṭlaʕ, yiṭliʕ "herausholen", isga, yisgi "bewässern")
The author notes "nur in Bildungswortschatz (aznab, aslam, aṣbaḥ u.e.a.)"
The author notes "nur in Bildungswortschatz (aznab, aslam, aṣbaḥ u.e.a.)"
The fourth form in Maltese is almost non-existent. It is only found in the verb 'wera' he showed.

cit.quote: he took something/ he expelled someone from something

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Form IV has almost completely dissapeared.
Form I and II are used instead of Form IV, e.g. karam instead of ʔakram "he honoured, welcomed."
This form exists but "either borrowings from MSA or emulation of the speech of other Arabs. Instead of Class IV verbs, Gulf Arabs use either Class I or Class II verbs. Examples ʕaṭa, ʕallam"

cit.quote: to wake up, get up in the morning

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Form IV in this dialect has mostly dissapeared and was replaced by Form I and II.

cit.quote: to wake up, get up in the morning

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Form IV in this dialect has mostly dissapeared and was replaced by Form I and II.

cit.quote: to wake up, get up in the morning

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Form IV in this dialect has mostly dissapeared and was replaced by Form II.
Deduced from examples
Note: "After a word ending in /a/ or /ā/ the initial hanza and vowel of the fourth derived form is elided, e.g. mā-xlaf"
IV with the prefix sa-
only for the word ʔaṭā 'to give' > aḥta, anṭa or anta
became like the I, ʔṣbaḥa > ṣbaḥ 'getting up in the morning'
